This material supersedes IRM 4.31.1, Pass-Through Entity Handbook, Introduction, dated 3-30-2017.

Field and campus personnel performing technical duties pass-through entities and/or their investors. LB&I plans to develop a separate Internal Revenue Manual (IRM). Until that occurs, LB&I personnel should check with their manager to see if the particular IRM section applies or if there is other guidance to follow.
Table of Contents

) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section provides an overview of terms and responsibilities for partnership examinations subject to and not subject provisions of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of

) Purpose : This handbook describes: • Types of TEFRA Agreements • Overview of the Pass-through Control System (PCS), formerly ship Control System • Explanation of the TEFRA Compliance Database Initiative (CDI) Database • Explanation of TEFRA and • Explanation of No
EFRA and Investor Level Statute Control (ILSC) returns (

) Audience : Field Revenue Agents (RAs), and campus RAs, Tax Compliance Officers (TCOs), Tax Examiners (TEs) and Clerks performing examination cedures for pass-through entities and/or their investors linked on the PCS. (
) Policy Owner : Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Headquar- ters Examination, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP). (
) Program Owner : Program Manager, Campus Examination and Field (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS). (
) Primary Stakeholders : SB/SE, Large Business and International (LB&I), Appeals. (

) Program Goals : Establish an electronic linkage between the partnership being examined and its underlying partners in order to generate notices required by statute; monitor and control statutes; and gather closing informa- tion. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
I, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section -Outside of Clearance. (
) TEFRA was passed in

to allow examinations and statutes to be con- trolled at the partnership level. This eliminated the need to control each individual partner statute. It also uniﬁed the litigation process whereby the nership ﬁles the petition rather than each individual partner. The PCS was created to establish an electronic linkage between the partnerships and their underlying partners. This helps ensure that all partners, no matter how complex the partnership structure, are issue notices and adjusted in a timely manner. PCS linkage allows the campus to performing examination for those partners the examiner doesn’t need so they can focus on examinations. PCS also allows the campus to systemically generate notices, control statutes, and gather closing information. (
) Section
of the Bipartisan Budget Act (BBA) of
repealed TEFRA nership and Electing Large Partnership (ELP) provisions beginning with tax years beginning

BBA has replaced TEFRA and ELP with a new tralized partnership audit regime. The new regime provides for assessment and collection of underpayments at the partnership level unless certain elections are made by the partnership.

) TEFRA was passed in

to allow examinations and statutes to be con- trolled at the partnership level. This eliminated the need to control each individual partner statute. It also uniﬁed the litigation process whereby the nership ﬁles the petition rather than each individual partner. The PCS was created to establish an electronic linkage between the partnerships and their underlying partners. This helps ensure that all partners, no matter how complex the partnership structure, are issue notices and adjusted in a timely manner. PCS linkage allows the campus to performing examination for those partners the examiner doesn’t need so they can focus on examinations. PCS also allows the campus to systemically generate notices, control statutes, and gather closing information. (
) Section
of the Bipartisan Budget Act (BBA) of
repealed TEFRA nership and Electing Large Partnership (ELP) provisions beginning with tax years beginning

BBA has replaced TEFRA and ELP with a new tralized partnership audit regime. The new regime provides for determination, assessment and collection of underpayments at the partnership level unless certain elections are made by the partnership.
Pass-Through Entity (
) Generally, all partnerships with tax years beginning after
will be subject to the BBA examination procedures. The law also allows eligible nerships with tax years that begin
to
to elect into the centralize partnership audit regime when they are initially notiﬁed of for audit (Early Election). (
) This IRM is still in effect for all TEFRA partnerships and Investor Level Control (ILSC) entities, and a new IRM will be developed for BBA (
) TEFRA policy was established in response to the partnership provisions of Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of

) Each designated campus will maintain a Campus Pass-through Function to establish and control, through Automated Information Management (AIMS) and PCS, any partner or shareholder returns related to key cases within its jurisdiction. The PCS will also be used to identify and establish linkage on second and subsequent tier entities. AIMS and PCS are also to identify and control indirect investors and/or pass-through entities. (
) The CPF is responsible for storing closed TEFRA key case admin ﬁles for least
months after the last investor’s one-year date. (
) Coordination between the CPF assigned the key case and the ﬁeld division (Examination and/or Appeals) examining the key case is critical to ensure all notices are issued timely. (
) Each CPF will complete an AIMS Inventory Validation Listing (IVL) at least annually or more often if necessary. (

) The Director, SB/SE, Headquarters Examination, Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) is responsible for: a. Ensuring that TEFRA policy and procedural changes are promptly mented through coordination with CPF personnel and with in the ﬁeld offices, area offices and territories of both the SB/SE and LB&I operating divisions; b. Monitoring and evaluating CPF operations and quality control c. Coordinating the resolution of CPF technical and operational d. Initiating the development of training modules for all levels of CPF employees; e. Updating IRMs
and
; and f. The establishment of assessment and refund tolerances used by the (
) Field Territory Managers and Field Area Directors are responsible for that TEFRA policies and procedures are followed. (
) Field Examination Managers are responsible for: a. Maintaining an updated copy of IRM
, Pass-Through Entity Handbook, in their respective functions; b. Ensuring the training of technical and clerical employees in TEFRA cedures; Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

4.31 Pass-Through Entity
This IRM is still in effect for all TEFRA partnerships and Investor Level Statute Control (ILSC) entities, and a new IRM will be developed for BBA
TEFRA policy was established in response to the partnership provisions of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of 1982.

Each designated campus will maintain a Campus Pass-through Function to establish and control, through Automated Information Management System (AIMS) and PCS, any partner or shareholder returns related to key cases within its jurisdiction. The PCS will also be used to identify and establish linkage on second and subsequent tier entities. AIMS and PCS are also used to identify and control indirect investors and/or pass-through entities.

Establishing PCS records and acting on PCS reports in a timely manner to assure an accurate PCS database.
The Director, SB/SE Examination - Brookhaven Campus and Director, LB&I Pass-Through Entities - Ogden, are responsible for:
a. The establishment and maintenance of pass

through suspense ﬁles; b. The establishment of correct PCS and AIMS databases; c. The effective use of PCS reports; d. The correction of database rejects; e. The timely processing of TEFRA notices; f. The development of appropriate controls to ensure timely and return and linkage establishment; g. Timely report writing; h. Timely assessments; i. The training of all employees in CPF procedures; and j. The timely notiﬁcation to the ﬁeld and the other CPF of signiﬁcant

The CPF manager is responsible for: a. Maintaining updated copies of the Pass-Through Entity Handbook in respective functions; b. Ensuring the training of their employees in CPF procedures; c. Establishing investor returns on PCS and AIMS; d. Maintaining correct data bases; e. Maintaining complete and accurate case ﬁles; f. Timely report writing and assessment of pass-through related or overassessments within the one-year assessment or Internal Code (IRC)
statute date; and g. Coordinating with other functions and the other CPF, as necessary. RAs (GS-
), TCOs (GS-
), and TEs (

) assigned or detailed to the CPF will perform all technical duties including coordinating with and other units within the campus, the other CPF, and ﬁeld offices nationwide. the duties of some technical employees may not be considered technical duties. Only time spent on technical duties should be included on the Form

Speciﬁc technical responsibilities include the following; a. Report writing of Individual Master File (IMF) and Business Master (BMF) reports; b. Review of the Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment (FPAA), Day, and linkage packages; c. Development and securing of statutory notice language; d. Classiﬁcation and screening of returns;

functions: a. Report writers; b. TAS (Taxpayer Advocate Service); c. Clerical units; d. Campus Program Analysis System (PAS); e. Other campus operations; f. Technical Services (TS); g. ) The campus TEFRA/Pass-through Coordinator will: a. Coordinate with campus and ﬁeld pass-through coordinators on case cessing b. Coordinate with Headquarters on any legal issues that need to be addressed by Chief Counsel; c. Review closing packages for completeness; d. Provide technical support to employees. (
) The campus PCS Coordinator is charged with: a. Identifying and resolving technical linkage problems b. Identifying and coordinating the resolution of PCS systemic problems (
) The CPF will be responsible for acknowledging Form
(Document mittal) within
days of receipt.
) Generally, key case CPF technical duties are determined by Operating Division. LB&I TEFRA and no
EFRA cases are worked at the Ogden Through Entities (PTE) Unit and SB/SE TEFRA cases and no
EFRA are worked at the Brookhaven Campus. (

) The key case CPF is responsible for: a. Linking investors through PCS; b. Issuing timely notices to investors; c. Receiving and executing agreements and settlement agreements; d. Establishing and maintaining the key case administrative ﬁle; e. Setting the one-year assessment statute date; and f. Preparing and mailing closing packages to functions (Compliance and Appeals) that have statute responsibility for investor returns. (
) Generally, the CPF services the investors according to the operating of the key case. (

) The investor CPF is responsible for: a. Securing investor returns; b. Creating and maintaining investor ﬁles; c. Identifying tiers; d. Linking tier investors; e. Writing reports of examinations; and f. Making pass-though related assessments on linked investors in their control. (

) Generally, the key case CPF and investor CPF are the same. They may the same if the investor is linked to key cases or tiers in more than one operating Division (i.e., LB&I or SB/SE). These are called multi-linked tiers investors. (
) Program Reports: Each year an exam plan is created for partnership nations. (

) Program Effectiveness: The exam plan is monitored to ensure the ship examination objectives are met. Open examinations are monitored to ensure a TEFRA determination is made and that the Tax Matters Partner (TMP) Notice of Beginning of Administrative Proceeding (NBAP) date is entered on Examination Returns Control System (ERCS). (
) Technical Services monitors a report to ensure TEFRA returns are a timely manner. The AIMS provides a report for TEFRA one-year statute dates, AMS
, that the ﬁeld monitors to ensure ﬁeld controlled Investor cases’ are completed timely. (
) There are several terms unique to TEFRA. Examples of these words:

Linking investors through PCS; Issuing timely notices to investors; Receiving and executing agreements and settlement agreements; Establishing and maintaining the key case administrative ﬁle; Setting the one
year assessment statute date; and Preparing and mailing closing packages to functions (Compliance Appeals) that have statute responsibility for investor returns.

Word Deﬁnition AAR Administrative Adjustment Request (AAR) - Notiﬁcation to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) of any subsequent change by a TMP or partner, to the treatment of a partnership item. The AAR is ﬁled by checking the appropriate boxes on Form 1065X, Amended Partnership Return, or by submitting Form 8082 (partnership level), Notice of Inconsistent Treatment or AAR, along with a claim for refund or an amended return. AAR proce- dures are in IRM 4.31.4. Affected Item Any item that requires adjustment as a result of an adjustment made to a partnership item. There are two types of affected items: computational and factual. Factual affected items are those that require a determination at the partner level. Campus TEFRA/Pass-Through Acts as a liaison between the Coordinator CPF and the ﬁeld offices, Appeals and counsel for both TEFRA and ILSC cases. They also provide technical support for the CPF. CCP Centralized Case Processing (CCP)- This function processes assessments and abatements and closes or transfers cases from the area to the campus or to ﬁles. CPF Campus Pass-through Function (CPF)- The CPF is the suspense unit for investor returns located in the Brookhaven and Ogden campuses. The two CPFs will be maintained to obtain and control, through the AIMS and PCS, any partner, shareholder or investor returns related to key cases within their jurisdiction. For details see CPF IRM 4.31.3 and IRM 4.31.6.

Word Deﬁnition FPAA Notice of Final Partnership Ad- ministrative Adjustment (FPAA) - The statutory notice of adjust- ments (as distinguished from a statutory notice of deﬁciency) in a partnership proceeding that is subject to judicial review in the Tax Court, the Court of Federal Claims, or the district court of the United States where the partner- ships principle place of business is located. Only partnership ad- justments are identiﬁed. An FPAA may also include penalties that are determined at the partnership level. FPAAs should only be issued by the Technical Services TEFRA/Pass-Through Coordina- tor or the CPF, and not ﬁeld agents. Investor Partner, Shareholder, or Beneﬁ- ciary - An investor return that reﬂects pass-through items from a pass-through entity return, which is controlled (via PCS and AIMS). Examples of investor returns includes, but is not limited to, Form 1040, Form 1041, Form 1120, Form 1120-S and Form 1065. Key Case A pass-through return established on PCS, usually a Form 1065, U. S. Return of Partnership Income or a Form 1120S, U. S. Income Tax Return for an S Corporation (NonTEFRA), that results in pass- through items to partners, shareholders, or investors (indi- vidual returns or another pass- through entity). Linkage The electronic relationship between a pass-through entity and its investor. LB&I Large Business and International. Serves corporations, subchapter S corporations, and partnerships with assets greater than $10 million.

Partner, Shareholder, or Beneﬁ- ciary - An investor return that reﬂects pass-through items from a pass-through entity return, which is controlled (via PCS and AIMS). Examples of investor returns includes, but is not limited to, Form

Word Deﬁnition LIN LB&I Imaging Network (LIN). The system used by LB&I to store images of returns. NBAP Notice of Beginning of Administra- tive Proceeding (NBAP) - The required notice sent at the start of an examination of a TEFRA part- nership to the TMP, and the copies of that letter sent to each notice partner. One-Year Date One-Year Date (OYD). This is a statute date applicable only to TEFRA partnerships. Adjustments to the partner returns must be made within one year of a ﬁnal partnership determination that ﬁnalizes the key case adjust- ments. PCS Pass-through Control System (PCS) (formerly, Partnership Control System) - Database used to establish an electronic linkage between a key case partnership and its underlying investors. The database is used to manage inventory, systemically generate notices, and control statutes. Record Information stored on the PCS database for a key case or an investor. SB/SE Small Business and Self- Employed (SB/SE). Serves taxpayers who ﬁle Form 1040, Schedules C, E, F or Form 2106, as well as small businesses with assets under $10 million. TMP Tax Matters Partner (TMP) - The designated partner to whom the Service looks as the primary rep- resentative of the partnership that is subject to a TEFRA proceed- ing. Technical Services Technical Services (TS) is the ﬁeld review staff.

Word Deﬁnition Technical Services TEFRA/Pass- The Technical Services TEFRA/ Through Coordinator Pass-Through Coordinator in Technical Services acts as a liaison between the area and the CPFs for both TEFRA and linked nonTEFRA cases. The ﬁeld examiner can locate their Technical Services TEFRA/Pass- Through Coordinator by searching their geographical area on the TEFRA web site’s TEFRA Coord Locator tab. TEFRA Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsi- bility Act (TEFRA) of 1982. The act did many things, but one of them was to unify audit and litiga- tion procedures for partnerships. We use TEFRA to refer to these procedures, and the affected returns. Tier A pass-through entity that is a partner of a pass-through entity. An S-corporation would be a tier partner of a partnership. 60-Day Letter Contains the letter (1827 or 1829) sent to the TMP and notice partners proposing adjustments to partnership items, notifying them of their right to ﬁle a protest to Appeals, the schedule of adjust- ments, and a Form 870-PT or a Form 870-LT. 60-Day letters should only be issued by the Technical Services TEFRA/Pass- Through Coordinator or the CPF, and not ﬁeld agents.

4.31 Pass-Through Entity

) This handbook will explain the procedures for conducting a coordinated pass- through examination from both the ﬁeld and campus perspective. The handbook is broken down into sections to allow the user to more easily ﬁnd answers to questions. Check sheets are provided as a job aid and to ensure consistency is maintained. (
) The examiner of a key case pass-through entity must understand the different types of entities, and how they are examined. (
) The key case examiner must also know how the tax returns of the related partners are eventually adjusted. (
) The terminology used in these sections to describe certain agreements or settlement agreements is provided below: a. Form

-PT, Agreement for Partnership Items and Partnership Level Determinations as to Penalties, Additions to Tax, and Additional This agreement form allows the partner to agree to adjustments proposed to partnership items. Penalties are determined at the partner- ship level for partnership years ending after
(See IRC
) Use this agreement form if only proposing adjustments to partnership items and partnership level penalties, but not to affected items. b. Form

-LT, Agreement for Partnership Items and Partnership Level Determinations as to Penalties, Additions to Tax, and Additional and Agreement for Affected Items. This form permits the partner to to both partnership adjustments and affected items or only partnership adjustments. A pass-through partner (i.e. a tier) cannot sign Part
of Form
-LT agreeing to affected items since a pass-through partner cannot bind its underlying investors. Only the ultimate taxpayers can agree to affected items. c. Form
-PT(AD), Settlement Agreement for Partnership Items and nership Level Determinations as to Penalties, Additions to Tax, and Additional Amounts. This is the appeals version of the Form
-PT. d. Form

-LT(AD), Settlement Agreement for Partnership Items and nership Level Determinations as to Penalties, Additions to Tax, and Additional Amounts and Agreement for Affected Items. This is the appeals version of the Form
-LT. (

) Signing an agreement or settlement agreement: a. Allows any partner to agree with the treatment in the partner’s return of the examination (or settlement) results of the key case. b. Removes the partner from any further partnership proceeding. c. The TMP or partner will be agreeing to all proposed adjustments unless partial agreement language has been included on the settlement agreement form signed. d. No subsequent claim may be ﬁled. e. The TMP can also agree for non-notice partners (partners holding less than a one percent proﬁts interest in a partnership with more than
partners) if the Form
-PT is modiﬁed to speciﬁcally state that the is binding non-notice partners. Generally, an agreement signed by the

a. Allows any partner to agree with the treatment in the partner’s return of the examination (or settlement) results of the key case. b. partners) if the Form

-PT is modiﬁed to speciﬁcally state that the TMP is binding non-notice partners. Generally, an agreement signed by the TMP, as TMP, should not be executed unless it was signed with the attempt to bind non-notice partners. f. All notice partners must sign their own separate agreements.

g. A settlement by a pass-through partner binds indirect partners to ments to partnership items and partnership level penalties, but not to affected items. h. Non-notice partners may elect NOT to be covered by an agreement may be entered into by the TMP, where the Form

-PT may be modiﬁed to allow the TMP to agree for the non-notice partners. This election is made by ﬁling a statement with the Service denying the the right to enter into such a settlement. i. The TMP cannot agree to affected item adjustments requiring proceedings for non-notice partners. Similarly, a pass-through partner cannot bind indirect partners to affected items. Note: All settlement agreements signed by a taxpayer must be properly by the Service before an agreement is binding. (

) The PCS is a computer system designed to control and monitor entity and linked partner returns. It does not replace AIMS inventory Control but it provides the additional information needed to control partner and (PCS), Formerly through returns and meet the legal requirements of TEFRA. The PCS is Control described in depth in IRM
, the Partnership Control System (PCS) Overview Handbook including information on special features, the various user letters, input documents, and indicators. IRM

) The PCS is a computer system designed to control and monitor pass-through entity and linked partner returns. It does not replace AIMS inventory control, but it provides the additional information needed to control partner and pass- through returns and meet the legal requirements of TEFRA. The PCS is described in depth in IRM
, the Partnership Control System (PCS) Handbook including information on special features, the various user reports, letters, input documents, and indicators. IRM
covers information related to
Note: The PCS IRM is titled Partnership Control System until the next revision.

) The TEFRA CDI Application is a work-around database designed to locally created Access database in PTE Ogden. The TEFRA database was designed to provide functionality the campus needed from a relational database that PCS can not provide. Both the TEFRA database and the application are temporary solutions until a more robust PCS redesign is complete. (
) Before TEFRA was enacted in

, partnership items appearing on and corporate taxpayer returns were determined by individual audits and notices of deﬁciency which included both partnership and nonpartnership items. Thus, multiple partners in the same partnership would be adjusted through separate proceedings unique to each partner. • Statutory Notice - Partner A • Statutory Notice - Partner B • Statutory Notice - Partner C Each notice suspended only the period for assessment for one partner and began a petition period for only that partner. Alternatively, the partner could allow the notice of deﬁciency to default, pay the tax, and ﬁle a claim/suit refund. Inconsistent results were possible. (

) The TEFRA changed the way the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) conducts examinations of those entities to which the TEFRA sections of the IRC Along with the changes to the examination process, speciﬁc time frames notice requirements were created. If these time frames and notice require- ments are not properly adhered to, no assessments are allowable against partner returns.

) The TEFRA changed the way the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) conducts examinations of those entities to which the TEFRA sections of the IRC apply. Along with the changes to the examination process, speciﬁc time frames and notice requirements were created. If these time frames and notice require- ments are not properly adhered to, no assessments are allowable against any partner returns.

(TEFRA), one partnership audit, notice and judicial proceeding binds all partners: a. One NBAP is sent to the TMP to signify the beginning of an audit. partners are sent copies. b. One FPAA is sent to the TMP informing him/her of the Service’s ment to partnership items. Notice partners are sent copies, if their partnership items have not converted to nonpartnership items. c. Only the FPAA notice to the TMP suspends the statute of limitations all partners and begins the petition period for a uniﬁed judicial ing. d. A petition based on FPAA may be ﬁled in Tax Court, District Court, or Court of Federal Claims. Only one petition based on the FPAA to the TMP may be ﬁled on behalf of all partners. Duplicate petitions will be dismissed. e. If the TMP does not ﬁle a petition within the ﬁrst
days after the was mailed, a petition may be ﬁled within
days from the close of
-day period by any notice partner or

percent group. f. The single petition that goes forward will bind all remaining partners gardless of whether they participate or intervene. If no petition is ﬁled, defaulted FPAA will bind all partners remaining in the partnership pro- ceedings. g. Once an FPAA is defaulted, no separate refund action is allowed to change partnership items. (IRC
(g) and IRC

(h)) Thus, all justments to partnership items that may result in a refund must be in a petition to the FPAA since this will be the sole opportunity to ﬁle a petition resulting in a refund. h. The Service computes the resulting assessments and refunds the default of the FPAA or the ﬁnal decision of the Tax Court. Petitions District Court or the Court of Federal Claims are treated as defaulted FPAA’s for assessment and collection purposes in order to preserve status of those forums as refund courts. (IRC
) i. Penalties are assessed using notice of deﬁciency procedures following partnership proceeding. For partnership years ending after August
, however, they must be determined at the partnership level and directly assessed following the partnership proceeding even if the they are computed on are affected items subject to deﬁciency (
) The uniﬁed audit and litigation procedures (IRC

) uniﬁed the dures in three respects: a. All partners are governed by one administrative proceeding and one docketed proceeding (if applicable). b. All deﬁciencies and refunds are determined based on the single proceeding. c. IRC
sets forth a minimum assessment period for all partners running from the date the partnership return is ﬁled or due to be ﬁled, whichever is later. (

) The existence of the CPF is to provide administrative assistance to the ﬁeld offices. The CPF ensures the TEFRA requirements or partner level statute controls are met in accordance with the applicable sections of the IRC. (
) If the examiner fails to utilize PCS and the CPF (which is mandatory for TEFRA), then the examiner assumes all of the responsibilities of the CPF Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
J
If the examiner fails to utilize PCS and the CPF (which is mandatory for TEFRA), then the examiner assumes all of the responsibilities of the CPF
page 13
including administrative functions, issuances of all notices, the recognition of and the actions required within the proper time frames and the proper resolu
tion of all of the related partner cases. The examiner must secure all of those returns for resolution. If a partner in a pass
through entity is itself another pass
through entity (a pass

through entity, also called a tier), then the examiner must also secure all partner returns of the tier. As long as this situation exists, the examiner must continue to secure and control all of the related returns. When the examiner utilizes the CPF, substantially all of the burdens of admin

istrative duties, time frames, notice requirements, partner examination report writing and tiering situations are shifted from the examiner to the CPF. The examiner is free to conduct the examination of the key case and the CPF will complete all of the required administrative functions.

) When the examiner utilizes the CPF, substantially all of the burdens of admin- istrative duties, time frames, notice requirements, partner examination report writing and tiering situations are shifted from the examiner to the CPF. Note: The examiner may choose to retain control of all the partners, but PCS linkage is still required.
